description: Originally justle (“to have sex with”), formed from Middle English jousten, from the Old French joster (“to joust”), from Latin iuxtā (“next to”), from iungō (“join, connect”), equivalent to joust +‎ -le.

entries.meaning: The act of jostling someone or something; push, shove.
examples: I had full hold of her Watch, but giving a great Jostle, as if somebody had thrust me against her, and in the Juncture giving the Watch a fair pull, I found it would not come, so I let it go that Moment, and cried out as if I had been killed, that somebody had trod upon my Foot  […]

entries.meaning: The action of a jostling crowd.
examples: For years to come, the average of lone women will be largely increased; and the demand, always great, for some means by which they many provide for themselves, in the rude jostle of the world, will become more urgent and imperative.

verbs.description: jostle (third-person singular simple present jostles, present participle jostling, simple past and past participle jostled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To bump into or brush against while in motion; to push aside.
(intransitive) To move through by pushing and shoving.
examples: Axia and Amory, acquaintances of an hour, jostled behind a waiter to a table at a point of vantage; there they took seats and watched.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be close to or in physical contact with.
(intransitive) To contend or vie in order to acquire something.
examples: Delivered them bound to the Pit and alive to the burning
Whither they mirthfully hastened as jostling for honour.

entries.meaning: (dated, slang) To pick or attempt to pick pockets.
